If you are up for the AI Health Data Challenge, read on for the details.
It is our goal to foster collaboration among disciplines and promote data-driven, evidence-based care. We are looking for UT students from diverse backgrounds with skills in information science, computer science, and medical science, to leverage their collective knowledge as a team and create an app for mining large datasets of electronic medical records. The app should produce valuable knowledge to support clinical decision making and present it through an effortless, immediate interface.
How to access the data
The challenge is based on the MIMIC-III database. All participants must use this dataset. There is a formal process for requesting access to MIMIC-III found here: https://mimic.physionet.org/gettingstarted/access/. You will need to pass the Human Subject Online Course from MIT in order to get permission to download the dataset. This process can take several days, so plan accordingly. Participants must agree to the MIMIC-III data use agreement. Please submit the completion report (not the certificate).
How to submit the deliverables
Please submit the following items before 11PM Central Time March 2 nd , 2020 to XYZ email:
● A 2-5 page report on the details of how you built the app. This report should contain the link to your GitHub, the details of your methods, and screenshots of your app.
● 5-minute video about your process.
Finalists will be announced on April 2, 2020. They will present their apps to a panel of health care experts on May 1, 2020, who will choose the winner at the end of the day.
To participate and connect with potential teammates, register by filling in this google form XYZ before Dec 1, 2019.
How to win
Your submission will be shortlisted by UT Austin faculty by March 22, 2020. The top teams will be invited to participate in a day-long seminar on April 3, 2020, where each team will present their work to a jury of healthcare professionals.
The judging criteria are:
● Usability
● Novelty
● Reproducibility
What you’ll win
1st prize: $1500; 2nd prize: $500
The two winning submissions will be made available on the AI Health website.
Deadlines
● Register at XYZ google form by December 1, 2019
● Final submission due by 11pm CST on March 2, 2020
● Announcement of finalists: March 22, 2020
● Presentation and judging: April 3, 2020
summary:
Big changes are on the horizon for all of healthcare. Access to ever-increasing amounts of data demands ever-evolving tools to harness and control this data for expert patient care. Where do these tools come from? Who can tame these unwieldy data sets? How can patient care be enhanced? AI Health wants to answer these questions through our Data Challenge.
AI Health is proud to issue the call to the students of The University of Texas to rise to this challenge and join us in providing cutting edge technology in evidence-based care that will be part of the changing face of healthcare.
title: Ai Health Data Challenge

summary: Drug control policy can have unintended consequences by pushing existing users to alternative, possibly more dangerous substances. Policies that target only new users may therefore be especially promising. Using commercial insurance claims data, we provide the first evidence on a set of new policies intended to reduce opioid initiation in the form of limits on initial prescription length. We also provide the first evidence on the impact of must-access prescription drug monitoring programs (MA-PDMPs), laws that do not target new users, on initial opioid use. Although initial limit policies reduce the average length of initial prescriptions, they do so primarily by raising the frequency of short prescriptions, resulting in increases in opioids dispensed to new users. In contrast, we find that MA-PDMPs reduce opioids dispensed to new users, even though they do not explicitly set out to do so. Neither policy significantly affects extreme use such as doctor shopping among new patients, because such behavior is very rare.  More information is available at: https://www.nber.org/papers/w25974
title: Can Policy Affect Initiation of Addictive Substance Use? Evidence from Opioid Prescribing
